awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Solid Earth response of the Patagonia Andes to post-Little Ice Age glacial retreat
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how the Earth responds to a cryospheric mass imbalance on
a time scale of centuries in a compact, well-monitored region of Patagonia, a region of complex Neogene ridge subduction and youthful volcanism. The problem of glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA) is an important problem and critical to understanding the viscosity and time-scales of deformation in the upper mantle. The PI team will try to quantify and model the isostatic response to ice and sediment loading and unloading.   A primary driver of modern rock uplift beneath and surrounding the Southern Patagonia Icefield (SPI) is interpreted to be ice loss following the peak advances of the Little Ice Age (LIA). Recent geodetic studies reveal remarkably rapid uplift rates (up to 40 mm/yr and averaging ~20 mm/yr around the SPI). These rates are the fastest modern geologic uplift rates; ones that demand a low viscosity mantle. In Patagonia, the presence of a somewhat poorly understood slab window that developed during Late Cenozoic time supports speculation that a low-viscosity zone underlies the region where GIA is very
rapid.

This team will explore the causes of high rates and spatial-temporal pattern of the inferred GIA using: (1) a regional broadband seismological array to delineate the crustal and upper mantle structure and viscosity and observe seismicity (currently undefined) along the subducting Austral slab; (2) shipboard reflection seismic data and sediment cores to image and date the young pro- and subglacial sediments deposited in the glacial troughs (now fiord-like lakes) carved by advancing ice with a goal of defining both the geometry of ice and volume of deposited sediment through time; (3) new mapping and dating of the subaerial morainal sequence to define the time-varying spatial geometry of the SPI along its two largest outlet glaciers; and (4) improved geophysical models of glacier and solid earth responses.

por.por_cntn:
The growth and demise of ice masses induces an isostatic response in the solid Earth, which is described by glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA). The rate and pattern of this response, measured by space gravity mapping and geodesy, contain the combined contributions of the lithosphere and mantle mechanical structure and of the evolving glacial environment. Resolving GIA therefore requires treating both model inputs—the Earth structure and the climate (as the forcing on the ice mass)—with equal fidelity and rigor.  GIA is therefore relevant to both our understanding of the solid Earth and of Earth’s future. 

The Glacial Uplift After Neoglaciation in the Andean Cordillera (GUANACO) project was designed to improve understanding of GIA mechanisms by focusing on the rapidly shrinking Southern Patagonian Icefield (SPI), where the fastest uplift rates on the world have been measured. Here, the combination of a complex tectonic setting resulting from the long-lived Chile ridge subduction and the largest temperate ice masses in the southern hemisphere result in increased sensitivity to surface loads; the region is therefore ideal for studying the centennial- to millennial-scale interdependence of Earth’s surface uplift and climate. We tested the hypothesis that the rapid uplift observed today results from a unique combination of rapid post-Little Ice Age (LIA) glacial retreat and aggressive erosion rates above an anomalously low-viscosity mantle. To test this hypothesis we collected and integrated four datasets: 1) a network of 27 broadband seismographs deployed around the SPI, to image and constrain the 3D mantle seismic and viscosity structure; 2) 250 km of high-resolution multichannel and 350 km of CHIRP seismic reflection data on the Lago Argentino proglacial lake, to derive submerged former ice frontal positions, rates and patterns of erosion/deposition; 3) 47 lacustrine cores (25 piston cores and 22 gravity surface cores with a total length of 108 m) extracted from the bottom of Lago Argentino, providing an annually resolved sediment record that constrains the climate history of the region over the last 5000 years; 4) terrestrial chronological data and mapping to refine the deglaciation history of the area. 

This research—the first to image the mantle south of the Chile Triple Junction (CTJ) under the South American continent—identified low mantle velocities throughout the inferred region of Chile ridge subduction, with the slower shallow mantle in the area of younger subduction, and anomalous mantle aligning with estimates of Antarctic slab edges and the trend of mapped volcanism at the surface. These results indicate the absence of lithospheric mantle near the CTJ, suggesting erosion due to mantle dynamics. Viscosities estimated from the seismic velocities indicate low viscosities in the ridge subduction region, and support higher uplift rates to the north of the SPI due to lower mantle viscosity (rather than greater ice mass losses). 

Using high-resolution seismic imaging integrated with coring of lacustrine sediment preserved in proglacial environment draining SPI outlet glaciers, we derived sedimentation rates and erosion rates at millennial to centennial timescales. We built age-depth models and yearly resolution sedimentation rate curves for each core through analysis of the varved sequences of the lake deposits using a newly developed varve-counting method. Spectral analysis of dominant periodicities within the sedimentary record identified three significant periodicities (200 ± 20, 150 ± 16, and 85 ± 9 years) and associated them with variations of the Southern Annular Mode, which is associated with changes in precipitation and temperature, and therefore with glacier recession and advance. Seismic reflection data illuminated the architecture of glacial submerged landforms preserved and buried under glaciolacustrine sediment, from which we reconstructed ice fronts from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to today, and calculated short- to long-term (102-103 yr timescale) glacial erosion rates for the Argentino ice lobe. 

The high-quality data identify a large-scale (~195 m thick, and >4 km long) thrust moraine complex associated with the Antarctic Cold Reversal, one of the most significant cooling events that interrupted the last deglaciation. The geometry and position of the structure indicates that the ice advanced rapidly, driven by both climate and local ice dynamics. Erosion rates calculated for the Argentino glacier lobe range between 4.89±1.76 mm/yr for the LIA glacial cycle to 1.21±0.72mm/yr for the LGM retreat, following a power law decrease with increasing time span, a behavior consistent with all Patagonian glaciers, regardless of latitude and glacier type. We observe that long-term (103 yrs) glacial erosion rates are comparable to those at orogenic time scales (106 yrs). Our results indicate that rapid glacial erosion rates, such as those measured during the LIA, are a transient response of glaciers to preglacial landscape reshaping. Estimated short-term (102yrs) erosion rates are one order of magnitude lower than current glacial isostatic adjustment uplift rates in the SPI, suggesting that isostatic adjustment in the region is currently driving mountain elevation.
